*   Seeker_A and Seeker_D rank Company_C last (P5), making it highly improbable they will apply to me unless all other options fail.
*   Seeker_B ranks Company_C 2nd (P2) and is likely applying to Company_E (B's P1).

If I reject Seeker_E, I risk Company_E accepting Seeker_B (B is E's P2), leaving me with very low prospects, as A and D won't come.

Securing a guaranteed P4 match in Round 1, especially from a candidate who highly prioritizes me, is a prudent strategy given the low likelihood of attracting my P1, P2, or P3 candidates early on. I will accept this match.
